facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 355 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 355 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal is by special leave from order No. 28 dated January 17, 1961 of the fourth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Case No. VIII-71.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order No. 28 dated January 17, 1961, of the fourth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Case No. VIII-71.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDREGADKAR, J. on March 19, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. March, 19. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDREGADKAR, J.-

facts.text: On March 14, 1960, Government of West Bengal referred six items of dispute to Fourth Industrial Tribunal between four employers and their employees.

anchor.surface_text: On the 14th March, 1960, the Government of West Bengal referred for adjudication to the Fourth Industrial Tribunal six items of dispute between four employers and their respective employees.

facts.text: Appellant is one of the employers: Ms. Serajuddin & Co., 16, Bentinck Street, Calcutta-1.

anchor.surface_text: Amongst the employers was the appellant M s. Serajuddin Co.,p-16, Bentinck Street, Calcutta-1,

facts.text: Items of dispute concerned employee claims for grade and scale, Dearness Allowance, House rent, leave and holidays, Provident Fund, Gratuity, and condition of service.

anchor.surface_text: and the items of dispute concerned claims made by the employees for grade and scale, Dearness Allowance, House rent, leave and holidays, Provident Fund and Gratuity, and condition of service.

facts.text: Workmen of three other industrial concerns filed affidavits stating they did not want to proceed as disputes settled.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that all the workmen employed in the three other industrial concerns filed affidavits before the Tribunal intimating to it that they did not want to proceed with the case because the dispute between them and their respective employers had been settled.

facts.text: Only dispute left for adjudication before Tribunal was between appellant and its workmen.

anchor.surface_text: That is how the only dispute which was left before the Tribunal for its adjudication was the dispute between the appellant and its workmen.

facts.text: Appellant raised preliminary objection that reference by State Government invalid as appropriate Government is Central Government under section 2(a).

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, a preliminary objection was raised against the validity of the, reference itself. It was urged that under s.2 a , the appropriate Government which could make a valid reference in relation to the present dispute between the parties was the Central Government and not the State Govt. of West Bengal

facts.text: Fourth Industrial Tribunal overruled the preliminary objection and set case for hearing on merits.

anchor.surface_text: This objection has been over-ruled by the Tribunal and the case has been set down for hearing on the merits.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Supreme Court by special leave against Tribunal's finding.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this finding that the appellant has come to this Court by special leave

facts.text: Appellant's office at Calcutta manages work of mines and sale of mine products.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants office at Calcutta generally manages the work of the mines and looks after the sale of its mine products.

facts.text: Appellant's mining operations carried on in State of Orissa under lease from that State.

anchor.surface_text: The mining operations of the appellant are, however, carried on the State of Orissa under a lease executed in favour of the appellant by the said State.

facts.text: Mining operations relate to chromite and manganese.

anchor.surface_text: These operations relate to the work of chromite and manganese.

facts.text: Calcutta office exercises general control over mining operations and looks after sale of minerals.

anchor.surface_text: The function of the Calcutta office is merely to exercise general control over the mining operations and look after the sale of the minerals produced in the said mines.

facts.text: Staff engaged in Head Office at Calcutta can be transferred to office in Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the staff engaged in the Head Office at Calcutta can be transferred to the office in Orissa where the mines are situated.

facts.text: Appellant employs staff at site of mines for direct supervisory control over mining operations.

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of exercising direct supervisory control over the mining operations, the appellant employs staff at the site of the mines.

facts.text: Appellant contends that Head Office at Calcutta is integral part of the mine.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sanyal contends that the Head Office of the appellant at Calcutta being an integral part of the mine, any industrial dispute between the said Office and its employees is an industrial dispute concerning a mine under s. 2 a (i)

facts.text: Court holds that the dispute is not an industrial dispute concerning a mine.

anchor.surface_text: Judged in that way, there can be no difficulty in holding that an industrial dispute between the employees engaged in the Head Office at Calcutta and the employer is not an industrial dispute concerning a mine.

facts.text: Head Office at Calcutta is not a mine.

anchor.surface_text: The Head Office is not a mine and so, an industrial dispute raised by the employees engaged in the Head Office is not an industrial dispute concerning a mine.

facts.text: Tribunal was right in holding that reference by State Government of West Bengal was valid.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the Tribunal was right in holding that the present dispute between the appellant and its employees at its Head Office at Calcutta is not a dispute in relation to a mine.

facts.text: Work in Head Office consists principally of sale operations after minerals are ready.

anchor.surface_text: The work that is carried on in the Head Office which consists principally of the sale operations really begins after the minerals are ready and all operations incidental to or connected with them are over.

facts.text: This position that Head Office work begins after mining operations is not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: This position is not disputed.

facts.text: Under Mines Act, office of the mine is not within definition of mine.

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that the definition of mine under s.2(j) excludes an office of a mine which is separately defined by s.2(k) as meaning an office at the surface of the mine concerned so that there is no doubt that the office of the mine, though it may be situated at the surface of the mine itself, is not within the definition of mine.

facts.text: Persons employed in Head Office not employed in a mine under Mines Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious that the persons employed in the Head Office wherever it may be situated cannot be said to do the mining operation within the first part of the definition. In our opinion, they cannot be said to be ordinarily engaged in any other kind of work which is incidental to or connected with mining operations either.
Appeal by special leave from the order No. 28 dated January 17, 1961, of the fourth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Case No. VIII-71.
This appeal by special leave raises a very short question about the construction of a part of section 2 a  of the Industrial Disputes Act
section 2 a  of the Industrial Disputes Act  I 4 of 1947  hereinafter called the Act . That question arises in this way.

issues.text: a very short question about the construction of a part of section 2(a) of the Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises a very short question about the construction of a part of section 2 a  of the Industrial Disputes Act I 4 of 1947  hereinafter called the Act . That question arises in this way.

arguments.court_reasoning: Mining lease rights do not define 'mine' in ID Act s.2(a)(i); use dictionary or Mines Act definition

arguments.claim: In s.2(a)(i), 'industrial dispute concerning a mine' determined without broad s.2(j) industry definition; mine means excavation per dictionary

anchor.surface_text: on the other hand, if we look at the definition in s.2 a  i , it would be numbericed that where it was intended to refer to an industry as such, the definition uses the word industry as for instance, it refers to industrial dispute companycerning only such companytrolled industry as may be specified in this behalf by the Central Government, whereas in referring to the dispute in regard to a mine the definition does number refer to an industrial dispute companycerning a mining industry but it merely says an industrial dispute companycerning a mine.

arguments.claim: Mine defined in Mines Act s.2(j) excludes office per s.2(k); head office employees not in mining operations per s.2(h)

anchor.surface_text: The mines Act  I 5 of 1952  also companytains a definition of mine in s. 2 j . The said definition shows, inter alia, that, a mine means any excavation where any operation for the purpose of searching for or obtaining minerals has been or is being carried on. It. is significant that the definition of mine under s.2 j  excludes an office of a mine which is separately defined by s.2 k  as meaning an office at the surface of the mine companycerned

arguments.claim: Head office work (sales) begins after mining operations complete, not incidental or connected

anchor.surface_text: The work that is carried on in the Head Office which companysists principally of the sale operations really begins after the minerals are ready and all operations incidental to or companynected with them are over. This position is number disputed.

arguments.claim: Central Government appropriate only for disputes concerning actual mines as per Mines Act scheme; head office outside

anchor.surface_text: The purpose of granting a mining lease obviously is to enable the lessee to search for and win minerals and, make them merchantable. The said purpose must necessarily include the right of the lessee to carry away the minerals and to dispose of them in the market. But the rights companyferred on the lessee under a mining lease can have numberdirect bearing on the question of the companystruction of s. 2 a with which we are companycerned.

arguments.claim: General rule: State Government refers disputes except specific exceptions in s.2(a)(i); mine exception narrow

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the Tribunal was right in holding that the present dispute between the appellant and its employees at its Head Office at Calcutta is number a dispute in relation to a mine.

holdings.text: in construing the words 'an industrial dispute in relation to a mine', we must first determine what a mine means and this must be done without reference to the broad definition of industry prescribed by section 2 j

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in construing the words ,an industrial dispute in relation to a mine, we must first deter. mine what a mine means and this must be done without reference to the broad definition of industry prescribed by section 2 j . In the absence of any definition of the word ,mine in.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual reading of s.2(a)(i) uses 'industry' explicitly elsewhere but refers to 'a mine' directly, requiring independent meaning of 'mine'

holdings.text: in the absence of a definition of the word 'mine' in the Act itself, we have to take either the dictionary meaning of the word or the definition of the word mine in the Mines Act

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any definition of the word ,mine in. the Act, we may take into account the dictionary meaning as excavation in earth for metal, companyl, salt etc. The mines Act  I 5 of 1952  also companytains a definition of mine in s. 2 j .

holdings.reasoning_summary: No definition in ID Act, so ordinary or cognate statute (Mines Act) meaning applies

holdings.text: the persons employed in the Head Office wherever it may be situated cannot be said to be ordinarily engaged in any other kind of work which is incidental to or connected with mining operations

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious that the persons employed in the Head Office wherever it may be situated cannot be said to do the mining operation within the first part of the definition. In our opinion, they cannot be said to be ordinarily engaged in any other kind of work which is incidental to or connected with mining operations either.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Head office sales work begins after minerals ready and mining operations complete; not incidental per Mines Act s.2(h)

holdings.text: an industrial dispute between the employees engaged in the Head Office at Calcutta and the employer is not an industrial dispute concerning a mine

anchor.surface_text: Judged in that way, there can be no difficulty in holding that an industrial dispute between the employees engaged in the Head Office at Calcutta and the employer is not an industrial dispute concerning a mine.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Mine' per dictionary/Mines Act excludes head office; employees not in mining/incidental work

holdings.text: The Head Office is not a mine and so, an industrial dispute raised by the employees engaged in the Head Office is not an industrial dispute concerning a mine

anchor.surface_text: The Head Office is not a mine and so, an industrial dispute raised by the employees engaged in the Head Office is not an industrial dispute concerning a mine.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct from exclusion of office in Mines Act s.2(j)/(k)

holdings.text: The rights conferred on the lessee under a mining lease can have no direct bearing on the question of the construction of s. 2 a

anchor.surface_text: But the rights conferred on the lessee under a mining lease can have no direct bearing on the question of the construction of s. 2 a with which we are concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mining lease purpose (including disposal) does not expand 'mine' definition in ID Act s.2(a)(i)

holdings.text: the Tribunal was right in holding that the present dispute between the appellant and its employees at its Head Office at Calcutta is not a dispute in relation to a mine

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the Tribunal was right in holding that the present dispute between the appellant and its employees at its Head Office at Calcutta is not a dispute in relation to a mine.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects integral part, industry def, mining lease arguments; applies narrow mine scope

holdings.text: the Tribunal was right in coming to the conclusion that the reference by the State Government of West Bengal in the present case was valid
holdings.reasoning_summary: Dispute falls under general rule s.2(a)(ii) State Govt, not exception s.2(a)(i) for mines

holdings.text: On general considerations also, the conclusion of the Tribunal appears to be right. The Central Government would be interested in industrial disputes in relation to a mine
holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy: Central interest aligns with Mines Act regulating mine labour, excluding offices
